reviewText:
Author's note:

Due to our good friends at adobe it makes my steam copy not record my actual playtime as is adobe's job to make my life lower quality so take my ingame time with a grain of salt.

FYI a tl:dr is at the bottom

Optimization:

First off we start off with another menu by adobe air.....wait what? Ok oddly enough no unity logos no unreal logo but adobe air? Literally the thing that only purpose is to make phone apps? To make matters worse whenever you start it up it has an unistall button right next to play button (perhaps a bit of foreshadowing right there).

Now once you get past that little ordeal you go to the options menu A.K.A the mute and not mute button(s) oddly enough there are two of them for all that i can tell are for headphones and speakers. There is no resoultion and iff you have a monitor like mine 1920 x 1080 prepare for the biggest black bars you will see on steam (although it turns out some of it is just your untextured inventory).

Plot:

You play as the brother of another brother who are apperently still not on a first name basis so from now on you play as bro 1 and you are looking for bro 2. Bro 1 comes back to england from...doesnt tell you ok, and you recieve a letter from your bro 2 telling you he found a break through in inter dimesional travel, but soon goes quiet and soon he goes missing along with the rest of his team, and can you guess his line of work in the pursuit of DIFFERENT DIMMESIONS? archeology....archeology....arc....E...ology. Well its good to note that the plot is as hair brained as the optimzation, but back on track you go to Tibet for some reason to his exact location...somehow and your adventure begins!

Graphics:

Ill say it now this is the one plus of the game, it feels like your inside of your journal as the MC writes down what he sees and tries to describe it through his doodles" (couldnt think of a better word). Though as i've said this game is odd so instead of creating an inventory in a POINT AND CLICK GAME you get 2 big
recommended:
bars boom now thats game design you think its just poor optimization but BAM it turns out its just untextured black screen who's laughing now?

note: it still has a bad resoultion i just found it funny how they made it worse.

Gameplay:

Ahh...the best for last

reviewText:
Abandoned is a short point-and-click adventure game, reminiscent of the escape-the-room flash games which I am so fond of.

There are some secrets to be found if you're paying attention to the surroundings.  One puzzle is going to be well-nigh impossible for those who are color blind, but there are walkthroughs that can help you with that if you need it.  There is also one place where I was stuck for a LONG time because I wasn't clicking in *exactly* the right place >_<  Luckily, only one of those spots in the game.

I don't know that the game is worth full price, but if you get it bundled for on a good sale, it's a nice short distraction (about an hour +)

reviewText: Why does banging a gong make handholds appear in a cliff face? Why does pulling a lever make an unpowered mine cart move itself? Why does changing the colors of 8 rooms make a cube turn into a lightbulb? Why is a gear with 12 teeth called a hexagon? Why do I need binoculars to look at a cube less than 2 feet away? Why does another cube turn into a lightbulb when you pull a lever? Why is the combination to the dimension door hidden in windows that need to have light shone through them, with lightbulb fixtures on the opposite side?\n\nThis game is not for people who like puzzles that make any sense at all. The art is pretty good, though.

reviewText: Nice short (~1 hour) room-escape puzzle/adventure.\n\nI have to explain the genre a bit: room escape" is a genre of small games (typically free flash games) that originally had you puzzle your way out of a locked room by searching the room and using objects and contraptions found within to ultimately find the key. There's no storyline (or not much of one)
date: often no hints or help (except for the obligatory Youtube video walkthrough)
recommended: and the door you need to open to escape is usually readily visible but locked. The genre then expanded to allow for multi-room scenes
hoursPlayed: and one of the most famous representatives is Mateusz Skutnik's "Submachine" series of games. Abandoned is so well done that many people (including Mateusz himself[www.kongregate.com]) found the parallels striking. It's a very good room escape game.\n\nYou can find Abandoned on the usual sites on the net. You can play it there for free

reviewText:
Short and sweet Point-and-Click adventure game.

Your brother went adventuring in the mountains of Tibet and found something mysterious and exciting.  But he disappeared, leaving only journal entries giving you tantilizing hints.  Follow in your brother's footsteps and discover the mystery!

The game consists of a sequence of screens that you can click left, right, up, and down to move (if possible depending on location) from screen to screen.  There are items you can pick up and use.  Unlike some other point-and-click games, this one does not hold your hand and show you possible moves.  Click everywhere until you figure it out.  Usable items will show up at the bottom of the screen in your inventory.  There are also journal entries your brother left behind that you can gather and read for clues.  Use the items by clicking on them in your inventory and dragging them where you want them used.

The puzzles are mostly logical and mechanical.  Though once or twice there were times when it didn't make sense because I could have done something in real life but the game wouldn't let me do it.  But overall they were good puzzles.  Some of these point-and-click games and hidden object games have crazy uses for items.  I'm happy to say that this is not one of them.

The graphics are a huge plus for me.  I love the cartoon look.  Or hand-drawn, or whatever it's called.  It just looks so cool to me.  But that's personal preference, and you can decide for yourself if you like the screenshots.

The music is just kind of spooky ambience background sounds.  Nothing special.  But it definitely fits the theme of the game.

Time to Finish: 1 hour or less.  Depends on how quickly you figure out the puzzles.  Also there are optional bonus items to find that reveal some more of the story.  You can find them along the way or return to the game after you finish.

Oh, and I guess there's a free version online somewhere.  Just so you know.
voteText: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This was a short and yet interesting PnC game. It's actually quite nice looking. It wont win any graphics awards, but it looks perfect for what it is.

All told, it took me around 45 minutes to complete. One puzzle in particular was quite difficult, but the others mostly involve finding pieces that you then go back to a previous area to use and unlock another area or another piece. Standard PnC fare.

The story itself was sparse, and yet completely worked within the scope of this game. It did feel like it ended prematurely, or at least felt like a cliffhanger from where a sequel would commence. No word on whether that will or wont happen, but in my opinion, it should.

I feel like this game is a nice interlude between other games. I'd say it is worth the asking price, but you may want to wait for it to reach dollar status before buying if you arent really into the genre or arent willing to take a chance on a shorter game. That said, it's definitely worth your time. It wont blow your mind, but you also wont regret playing it.

I think all told, I'd give this around a solid 7 of 10.

reviewText:
HD version of a free flash game (google it), so don't expect a long game. I liked the sound effects and ambient music, and most of the puzzles are OK (except for one pixel hunting part and a puzzle that requires you to take notes and not be color-blind to solve).

I definitely do not feel like I wasted my time playing this, so I think you'll probably like it.

Recommnended, but only on a huge sale or in a bundle.

Pros:

- Relaxing music and sound effects
- Simple graphics that suit the game
- Most puzzles are intuitive

Neutral:

- Short (for me this can be a pro, depending on the price I paid)

Cons:

- Pixel hunting (once in the game)
- Color-based puzzle that got me stuck (in-game tips are not easy to check and I could not find the way back to check the in-game hint again, so I had to use the official walkthrough)
- Long corridors (lots of going back and forth to solve the puzzles)
- Bad English (but good enough to understand it)
- Can be played free of charge on the web (flash game)

reviewText:
I wish there were a sideways thumb option. Some sort of way to express a middling response or rather to set one up quickly.

This game is completely FREE on many websites using a browser that supports flash. Just do a quick google search. Luckily I got this in a trade and valued it well under the price here in the store.

It doesn't do anything egregious, similarly it doesn't do many or really anything new. Its extremely short. The puzzles are traditional in the way that trial and error usually ends up being the method of passage rather than any actual puzzle solving. Though there are some memorization bits. There is a even a button on the top of the screen that links to a youtube walkthrough.

I will say it does a decent job at creating an ominous atmosphere however.

reviewText:
I want a sideways thumb because this game has potential to be a real PC game instead of a browser game.

I like the idea but the puzzels are a little confusing. I only used the wikipedia near the very end for the fourth light bulb but I walked around alot. The secerets are a nice touch but easy to find. The game being made in flash makes the game to go below 30 FPS although my computer sucks, this is still a problem. One of the major problems that I had were the glitches. Suprisingly none of these were game breaking except one but that was fixed with a restart. For some reason, at least for me, I could see other panes while in each individual pane and this allowed me to move to parts of the level that would be otherwise impossible without doing the proper steps to do it vanilla. This allowed me to skip a very large part of the game, that invloves a broken train, and get to the next part. Now I did not know this until I watched a walkthrough but I could have completed the game without ever going through that part. In other parts, it just looks ugly. This could be a problem when playing in higher resolutions such as 1920 x 1080. The length of the game is short as it only took me less than 2 hours to complete. This game may or may not be the game for you but I enjoyed the story and I want this to be a positive review.

I understand how lame this review is but I suck at reviewing games. On a last thought there should be Achievements and better optimization.

Look I'm putting a positive review but it is borderline not worth youe money at the moment.

reviewText:
This is a short point and click adventure with some unique and novel concepts added. It's similar in some fashion to a masterpiece called 'Rhem' in that the puzzles themselves hold the atmosphere of the game as well as help tell a story. The developer is from the Ukraine and can be found here... http://krutovig.com/about-me/

The biggest disappointment here is that English is not his native tongue and that is particularly evident when you compare the grammar and literacy of the various notes hidden around the place which tell a hodge podge story thrown together from all sorts of various inspirations starting from the movie 'Cube' to the game 'Metro 2033'. Having said that you can also tell that the developer is really trying to produce something which gives you a sense of wanting to explore and solve the mystery of an alien landscape.

Here lies the gem of the game. The map layout is actually really well designed and the puzzles compliment the whole entire journey without it being that hard at all. In fact even though an ingame connection to a walk through is kindly provided by the developer it's hard to imagine that you will need one as there are plenty of clues to the observant eye. Just as you begin to get immersed in this out of world experience the story finishes with a question mark and another door which leads to his sequel of this game 'Abandoned 2'.

Also there is four magical letters you can find and hilight which will present you with four additional diary entries by your brother as a special ending if you care to go that extra mile.

In final I really did appreciate this short adventure and will be looking at his next. I do suggest that the developer seriously thinks about hiring or gaining the confidence of a volunteer writer which could help enhance this story. As for map and puzzle layout, you seem to have nailed it by presenting a worthy enjoyable experience. The cartoon or animation could do with some slight tweaking by adding in a more detailed artwork and beautiful backgrounds. Having said that it was still quite justifiable though it seemed cheaply drawn because of its numerous unique settings it constantly presented to you.

You seem to be on a good thing here, hopefully with further improvements in both art and story this game will never truly be abandoned.

reviewText:
Short version: 61%Thirty minutes of game play, where twenty is spent by clicking through repeating empty corridors, and the rest solving a few surprisingly clever puzzles.

Long version:Abandoned is the kind of game where there are no dialogues, no cut-scenes, just about fifty or so screens – of which roughly half serve no purpose other than being a filler transition area – and the real content, the puzzles. They are quite okay for this price and game time range (of about 30 minutes). There is one that requires an ungodly amount of backtracking and one where you need good colour and 3D vision to even have a hope solving it, but otherwise they are fairly balanced and unique.

There is a plot for all of this, but you barely recognise it. Not only it is short, but it feels more like a prologue to something than an actual story. Still, it gives you some motivation to continue on… I guess… so, it does its job.

reviewText:
Very short but neat point-and-click game similar to the Submachine series.

While the result of some puzzles (e.g. using a gong makes stone steps appear) may not seem logical to you, keep in mind that the game is set in a fictional place and things like that are very common in this kind of game.

With that in mind, you don't have to perform mental gymnastics in order to solve these puzzles. Actually, this game is rather easy. I finished it in less than an hour.

May not be worth 3$ but give it a shot if you can find it in a bundle. :)

reviewText: I feel rather disappointed. The game is short and badly integrated with Steam; the puzzles are mostly obvious, but sometimes very obscure (primarily those coloured chambers); the plot (of Lovecraftian roots, I assume) leaves an impression that this is rather an intro to the actual game. The art, the ambient and the atmosphere are quite well, but I expected more and now feel unsatisfied. Considering all this, it is no wonder that the game's title now seems to me a bad omen.

reviewText: I got this game in a bundle and while fun, it's also available free online, which a simple google search can tell you. If you get the game in a bundle, you can play it in Steam if you want, but there's no achievements or cards to be had. It was a fun game and I recommend it if you already own it or you want to find it online, but I wouldn't reccomend paying for it. There also isn't anything extra in the Steam version because the walkthrough I had to use for some parts (some puzzles are very convoluted and require lots of walking back and forth to find the right things) was for the online versions and took me all the way through the game.\n\nTLDR: If you have it already, play it. If you don't, go play it for free online. It's fun, but unless you want to donate to the developer, don't buy it on its own.

reviewText: This game wasn't what I thought it was.  My fault for not reading other peoples' reviews, but it is a simple Flash-based room escape game that has a meaningless plot and some decent puzzles, but nothing too difficult.  It can be finished in approximately a half hour to forty-five minutes depending on the player, and then it's done.\n\nMy downthumb is simply for this version of the game.  By all rights, it's a decent room-escape and a nice little time killer that's decently thought out.  I just don't know why there was a commercial release when it's available everywhere.  Still, I hope it allows Krutovig to explore bigger ideas and maybe come up with something much more profound in the future.

reviewText:
This is going to be a recommendation with a caveat.

Personally, I like this game.  I think it's a decently clever point and click adventure, that offers an interesting setting and doesn't succumb to adventure game logic too much.  The puzzles might be a bit on the easy side, and the story itself could probably use a bit more fleshing out, the former I think works well enough for a game like this and the latter is largely because this is just the start of a potential series.

Here comes the caveat though: there is a free version of the game available online (also posted by the developer), and in fact the steam version doesn't have any less features than the free version.
So it might only make sense to buy the game if one wants to support the developer.  Otherwise, I would say keep any eye on it but maybe hold off on a purchase.
Though the game isn't that expensive, so you wouldn't lose much either way.

reviewText:
(As others have said, the game is available for free elsewhere on the internet, but I believe the graphics are a slightly better resolution in this version.)

Production values:
I really enjoy the hand-drawn art style, and the music does a good job of creating an otherworldly atmosphere. Also, unlike other commenters, I had no problems installing or running the game on my laptop. It was a smooth, glitch-free experience.

Gameplay:
The puzzles are fairly intuitive, and if you are willing to think creatively and pay attention to details, you will not need to resort to a walkthrough. I personally liked the challenge level, it was a brainteaser without being frustrating.

The tone of the game is supernatural in nature, so don't expect everything you see to make sense; however, there is a solid adventure-gaming logic behind each of the puzzle solutions. (Ex. Why does hitting a gong have the effect it does? Who knows? But you don't need it to make sense to understand the simple item-combination puzzle behind it: You know you need to hit the gong, therefore you know you need something to hit the gong with. You can easily suss that out on your own.)

My only complaint is there were one or two hotspots that could have been implemented better (I'm looking at you, Secret #3).

Story:
This was where the game started to fall apart for me. The plot is a rough outline at best, and is mainly a hodge-podge of vague sci-fi and adventure tropes. It doesn't feel like it has any real substance, and there wasn't enough of a payoff at the end for finding all the hidden clues. It just left the game on a hollow and abrupt note. I understand this is the first in a planned series of games, but I am still left with a lingering sense of is that all?" I think if the game had been a bit longer
date: with a more substantially developed plot
recommended: it would have been more satisfying.\n\nAs is
hoursPlayed: this is a decent point-and-click puzzler that will give you 45-90 minutes of brain-teasing fun. The graphics and music are great
voteText: and the story is not-so-great
helpfulPercent: but overall the gameplay is solid.\n\nI would give it a 7/10. If you are unsure about it
votesHelpful: play it online for free. If you like it and want to own a copy
votesTotal: it's worth paying a dollar or two to support the creator."

reviewText:
I liked it. It's a short, simple point and click adventure. It doesn't take too long to solve, although there are a couple of puzzles that are a little infuriating - it's not that those ones are hard, more that I really couldn't be bothered going through the steps of solving them. But I did and I managed to finish it.

As you can see from my play-time in game, it took me half an hour to finish. I don't have a problem with that for the sake of a few pence. Heck, I made the money selling trading cards (for other games) so it didn't cost me anything.

Short, simple, clever in places and worth half an hour to an hour of my time. Jolly fun.

reviewText: The puzzles" in this game
date: make no sense. First playthough got a glitch with the box at the top of the mountain so couldn't get it. Second playthrough got a glitch in the cubes where I couldn't get out anymore (or is that supposed to happen?) At any rate
recommended: no fun to be had with this game for me. I wouldn't say I am bad at puzzles
hoursPlayed: but when they don't make sense then I can't be bothered. Of course the fact that there's a direct button to a walkthrough inside the game proves my point. A good game with puzzles that make sense doesn't need a walkthrough
voteText: at least definitely not one linked directly inside the game by the developer itself. The developer should simply have made the game itself more logical and clear. I am honestly not inclined to just watch the walkthrough and shadow every move from it in the game. Also this game's available for free on some other websites."
